 The article isn't credible as it neglects a number of important factors that would change the conclusion drastically -- even if the conclusion appears sound (i.e. the use of prescribed drugs had a negative impact on the children's ability to learn and linked to increase in violent behavior).
 
 1. The article did not include any significant discussion that compares violent behavior between students who took the drugs (allegedly 9 million of them) and students who did not.
 
 2. The article did not compare actual number of violent incidents. Instead, it compared fatalities as if all violent behavior led to deaths. It is more difficult to kill someone with your fists than with a gun.
 
 3. The article did not include any significant discussion on any trends on number of violent students. Instead, it only compared the number of fatalities. One student in 1980s killing a person using a baseball bat versus one student killing five others with a shotgun a decade later. How do you compare? In both cases, there was only one violent student but the increase in fatalities was five-fold. You cannot assume that violence is increasing based on the number of fatalities, particularly since it is so much easier to do mass killing with a machine gun than with a baseball bat.
 
 4. The article does not include any significant discussion on any increases or decreases on total student population. If the student population in any given area increases by a factor of five, it should not be surprising to see violent behavior to increase at a similar rate.

 I for one agree with it and would like to add my thoughts. (and might as well make some enemies with my first post)
 I find fault with the mindset of today's youth as instilled in them by their teachers.
 
 Today's youth have been fed the gruel of "self-esteem" from an early age and this indoctrinated non-judgmental theory is biting us in our rump. Kids are told from the earliest age that they are an outstanding person, that it is "not fair" to judge others or yourself. 
 
 "Johnny, just because you had 14 out of 20 questions wrong, does not mean you are a bad person, you had six right, you are a beautiful snowflake!" 
 
 So our kids are told not to get down on themselves because they fail at such un-important normal tasks; judging is wrong . . . to enhance themselves they should express themselves in whatever manner they wish. Green spiked hair? OK. Multiple facial piercing? OK. Do whatever makes you "feel good about yourself."
 
 Then the contradictions come; UH, wait, you can't say this, or that. A rare few ever find out that their contrived "individuality" is nothing but diversion to ensure conformity; to question authority or the conventional classroom wisdom as dispensed by the "teacher" is frowned upon.
 
 They quickly learn that such empty, indoctrinated self esteem is like lounging in a Jacuzzi. The warm water and bubbles feel great, and one could delude themselves into thinking that it will never end. Soon though they are forced to get out and go out into the cold, harsh world. That bitter wind is often first felt in others' negative views and opinions of them. Puberty sets in with all the self doubt and worries of fitting in and they begin to learn the very hard lesson that not everyone thinks they are an outstanding person. In fact, some people think they're a jerk and wouldn't urinate on them if they were on fire. When that happens, egotism is threatened. Teenagers usually react in one of three ways. 
 
 1, They put on the "down parka" of a healthy, true self-image, based on a moral code, their accomplishments, character and ethics and an understanding that life is not always kind or fair. They strive to work harder and better their situation regardless of what others may think, or their motivations.
 
 2, Since they have only been told that they are wonderful and never understanding why they are wonderful, they simply lower their self-esteem, say "I don't deserve to be warm and comfortable" and withdraw to a corner and "shiver" alone, in the worst cases, they contemplate suicide. 
 
 3,Those with an anti-social bent maintain and nurture their unwarranted high self-esteem by manifesting negative emotions toward either the source of the ego threat or, most often, those weaker and of lesser social status. In one form, this is exhibited as bullying behavior. On the opposite spectrum, with a bully's victim['s], it becomes a "who the F' do they think they are screwing with . . . everyone must pay" directive to punish the slights against them. From that comes the Columbines.
 
 As a side note, I find it interesting that many here wish to frame the school violence problem in only the headline making shooting massacre genre. That is like trying to discuss the dangers of electricity and only discussing lightning . . . This problem exists on so many levels, to reduce it to the rarity dismisses the everyday hurt that our kids experience.

Everyone says that they want more rules or more enforcement of rules in the schools until it is their little Johnny or Susie and then they want an exception because teachers don't "understand" the situation. Schools are nothing more than a reflection of the society at large. Do we live in a violent society? Yes. Do we see people getting away with breaking the rules? On so many levels, it's not even funny! Until we give schools the right to operate according to stated principles, with due process rights (yes, schools and teachers make mistakes, too) for students/parents, and insist to the public at large that we WILL provide a safe environment for our students, we are simply keeping violence down to a low roar and hoping for the best.
 
 On bullies. There have always been bullies in school, we all remember them. Teaching students that there are consequences for their actions is the only way to put the brakes on the outside world infiltrating the schools. We don't have legislation forcing parents to teach their children respect for self and others, consequences for their actions or a host of other general values that most people would deem necessary to the appropriate upbringing of a child. Schools do what they can with what they have, which in terms of authority is precious little.

The rest of the statement was that students need to be taught the consequences of their actions, which is part of the solution to the problem of bullies and victims. It was also in reference to bullies always being a part of the landscape, but one didn't hear about school shootings until the last 15-20 years. So obviously something else is going on with young people outside of just being bullied, or we would have had school shootings throughout the history of mandatory schooling.
 
 A question. Why should schools be safe places when the world outside of the schools are not safe? Those unsafe places include the child's home (domestic violence at all time highs), the neighborhood in many instances(street crimes), and the world at large. Don't get me wrong, I wish the schools could be an oasis of safety for students, and in many cases, they are the safest place that many kids will be on any given day, but if kids bring the outside problems into the schools with them, only so much can be done at the school level. I always enjoy reading posts that say the school personnel should be doing more to safeguard the students and should know the students as well as their parents do because kids are at school all day. Let's analyze this idea. The parents have the children for the first 4-5 years of life depending on whether the kids go to kindergarten or not. Students generally get out of school sometime between 2:30 and 3:30 depending on the grade level and most don't go to bed until 8:00 (young) -11:00(older). That's 51/2 - 71/2 hours that a parent could spend with their children. Ah, you say, but most parents work and don't get home until at least 6:00. Sorry, but that is the parent's choice. And yet many insist that the teachers should know the children as well as the parent does. I'm not quite sure how everyone else does math, but in my case I have 30 students per 55 minute class period, 5 classes per day. If a parent can't tell when something is up with their children, for argument's sake, let's say they have a large family by today's standards, 4 children, how in the world does anyone expect me, as the teacher to know my students on a deep level? I try very hard to note behavioral changes, but unless they are really obvious (sleeping in class, sudden disruptive behavior not present before, etc.) I am probably not going to pick up on a subtle change. I always love the parents who come in to a conference, usually initiated by the teachers because of a concern, and the parents ask us what they should do about their child because the kid won't listen to them or do what they say. Again, what is it you would like me, the teacher to do with your child? You gave birth to the child, raised him/her for the first 4-5 years, can choose to spend time with the child after school and on weekends, and can choose to make and enforce rules for your child from a very early age. Ultimately, I can only have an influence on your child for 55 minutes/day during which time they are 1 of 30, and I am also supposed to teach them something about the subject matter of the class along the way.
 
 Possible solutions to school violence lie in addressing societal problems at large such as, poor parenting, gratuitous (sp) violence in the media (no it doesn't teach kids to be violent, but it sure does give some ideas), corruption at the highest levels with no consequences for their actions, glorification of street gangs, drug culture, the fast buck with no hard work involved, apathy about the importance of an education whether it be college, trade or vocational school, the value of a work ethic, unbridled consumerism, the idea that the world owes one something simply because one is breathing, and the list goes on and on.
 
 Public schools were not designed to raise the children of our society. They were designed to teach subject matter and to reinforce appropriate behavior learned at home, or correct inappropriate behavior, but not be the teachers of appropriate behavior. If society now wants the schools to teach all aspects of life to youngsters, say so, then get out of our way, quit interferring when we do something you don't like and let us do our jobs. OR if schools are to do what they were designed to do then YOU raise YOUR children and we will teach subject matter and reinforce appropriate behavior and correct inappropriate behavior.
 
 I'm sorry to tell you this, but you can't have it both ways. Please chose one, so we can do our jobs to your satisfaction.
